solution.text:
By observing the figure carefully we can see that top and bottom portions are segments of a circle with centre O
\(\Rightarrow r_1=OC\, and \,r_2=OA\)
As ABCD is a square, by using Pythagoras we can get AC
\(AC=\sqrt {AB^2+BC^2}=\sqrt {2\times AB^2}= \sqrt 2\times AB\)
Now we know at the point of intersection the diagonals bisect each other
So, OC=OA\(\Rightarrow OC=\frac {AC}2\Rightarrow OC=\frac {\sqrt 2\times AB}2=\frac {AB}{\sqrt 2}\)
\(\Rightarrow OC=OA=r=_{{trunc(j/Decimal('1.414'),2)}}_\)
Now area top and bottom portion = \(2\times [\frac {90}{360}\times \pi \times r^2- area(\bigtriangleup AOD)]= 2\times _{{trunc(Decimal('0.25')*pi_val*j*j/2,2)}}_-2\times area(\bigtriangleup AOD)\)
\(\Rightarrow _{{trunc(Decimal('0.25')*pi_val*j*j,2)}}_-[2\times \bigtriangleup AOD]\)
Now, \(\bigtriangleup OAB \cong \bigtriangleup ODC \Rightarrow area\,of \bigtriangleup OAB = \bigtriangleup ODC \)
Area of the shaded region= Area(top segment) + Area(bottom segment) + area\(\bigtriangleup \) OCD + area\(\bigtriangleup \)OAB)
Area of the shaded region=\(2 \times _{{trunc(Decimal('0.25')*pi_val*j*j/2,2)}}_-[2\times \bigtriangleup AOD]+ 2\times [\bigtriangleup ODC]\)
Hence area of the shaded region _{{trunc(Decimal('0.25')*pi_val*j*j,2)}}_
